title: 108_hr1800
content: The United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by banning their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. Penalties are imposed for prohibited acts. It is illegal to import, export, or transport fur or steel-jawed leghold traps in interstate commerce. Penalties are imposed for violations of these prohibitions. Violation of the prohibition on importing, exporting, or transporting steel-jawed leghold traps may result in imprisonment for up to 5 days or fines under title 18, United States Code. Subsequent violations can lead to imprisonment for up to two years or fines under the same code. SEC. 3. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to anyone providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Officers or employees of the government are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces this Act and its rules, utilizing personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import violations are treated as customs law violations, while export violations are enforced using the Export Administration Act of 1979. The customs laws of the United States and provisions relating to violations shall apply to this Act. Export violations will be enforced using the Export Administration Act of 1979. Enforcement authorities may detain, search, and seize packages if there is reasonable cause to suspect violations. Enforcement authorities have the authority to detain, search, and seize packages if there is reasonable cause to suspect violations of the Act. They can also make arrests without a warrant for violations committed in their presence or with probable cause. Additionally, they can execute and serve arrest and search warrants. Enforcement authorities have the power to detain, search, and seize packages based on reasonable suspicion of Act violations. They can arrest without a warrant for violations witnessed or with probable cause, and execute warrants issued by judges for Act enforcement. Forfeiture rules apply to articles of fur or steel-jawed leghold traps in violation of the Act, subjecting them to forfeiture to the United States. This includes seizure, forfeiture, and disposition procedures similar to customs laws violations. Under this Act, property subject to forfeiture to the United States will be dealt with according to provisions of law related to seizure, forfeiture, disposition, remission, mitigation, and compromise of claims. Enforcement duties for seizure and forfeiture of property will be similar to customs laws. Under this Act, the Secretary or authorized officers may enforce seizure and forfeiture of property, similar to customs laws. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators. Cooperation is required from the Secretary of Commerce. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators of the Act. The Secretary of Commerce, Treasury, and other relevant agencies must cooperate to ensure effective enforcement. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" refers to any furskin or article made in whole or part of furskin. The term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" describes a device designed to capture animals by snapping closed on their limb. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to any law or regulation enforced by the US. The term "import" means to bring into the United States. The term "interstate commerce" is defined in section 10 of title 18, US Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary has the authority to create rules for implementing the Act, which will become effective one year after its enactment.
